title: Tom Manley (footballer)
text:
Thomas Ronald Manley (7 October 1912 – 4 July 1988) was an English professional <a href="association%20football">football</a> <a href="Utility%20player%23Association%20football">utility player</a> who made over 300 appearances in the <a href="Football%20League">Football League</a> for <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a> and <a href="Brentford%20F.C.">Brentford</a>. He later managed hometown club <a href="Northwich%20Victoria%20F.C.">Northwich Victoria</a>.
Playing career.
Early years.
Manley began his career with junior clubs Brunner Mond and Norley United, before joining <a href="Cheshire%20County%20League">Cheshire County League</a> club <a href="Northwich%20Victoria%20F.C.">Northwich Victoria</a> in 1929. He remained at <a href="Drill%20Field">Drill Field</a> until September 1930.
Manchester United.
Manley was brought to <a href="Football%20League%20First%20Division">First Division</a> club <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a> by <a href="Scout%20%28association%20football%29">scout</a> <a href="Louis%20Rocca">Louis Rocca</a> on an amateur basis in September 1930. At the end of the <a href="1930%E2%80%9331%20Manchester%20United%20F.C.%20season">1930–31</a> season, after the club's relegation to the <a href="Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Second Division</a>, he signed a professional contract. Manley broke into the team over the course of the <a href="1932%E2%80%9333%20Manchester%20United%20F.C.%20season">1932–33</a> and <a href="1933%E2%80%9334%20Manchester%20United%20F.C.%20season">1933–34</a> seasons and scored 15 goals in United's <a href="1935%E2%80%9336%20Manchester%20United%20F.C.%20season">1935–36</a> Second Division title-winning campaign. After suffering relegation straight back to the Second Division at the end of the <a href="1936%E2%80%9337%20Manchester%20United%20F.C.%20season">1936–37</a> season, he helped the team to an immediate return to the top-flight one season later. <a href="1938%E2%80%9339%20Manchester%20United%20F.C.%20season">1938–39</a> was Manley's final season at <a href="Old%20Trafford">Old Trafford</a> and he finished his Manchester United career having made 195 appearances and scored 41 goals. Predominantly an <a href="outside%20left">outside left</a>, he also performed the role of a <a href="Utility%20player%23Association%20football">utility player</a> at Old Trafford by also playing in <a href="Half%20back%20%28association%20football%29">half</a> and <a href="Full%20back%20%28association%20football%29">full back</a> positions.
Brentford.
Manley joined First Division club <a href="Brentford%20F.C.">Brentford</a> for a "substantial fee" in August 1939 and was immediately named <a href="Captain%20%28association%20football%29">captain</a>. Just three matches of the <a href="1939%E2%80%9340%20Brentford%20F.C.%20season">1939–40</a> season were played before the season was abandoned and competitive football was <a href="Association%20football%20during%20World%20War%20II">suspended for the duration</a> of the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>. Manley's duties with the <a href="RAF">RAF</a> meant that he appeared sparingly for the club during the war, making just 36 appearances and scoring six goals by the end of the <a href="1945%E2%80%9346%20Brentford%20F.C.%20season">1945–46</a> season. Competitive football resumed for the <a href="1946%E2%80%9347%20Brentford%20F.C.%20season">1946–47</a> season and Manley would go on to make 122 appearances and scored 8 goals for the club before making his final appearance in September 1950. He remained as <a href="Griffin%20Park">Griffin Park</a> as a <a href="Brentford%20F.C.%20Reserves%20and%20Academy%23Reserve%20team">reserve team</a> player for the <a href="1951%E2%80%9352%20Brentford%20F.C.%20season">1951–52</a> season (playing one match as a <a href="Goalkeeper%20%28association%20football%29">goalkeeper</a>) before retiring at age 39 in May 1952. Manley was awarded a joint-<a href="Testimonial%20match">testimonial</a> with <a href="Ted%20Gaskell">Ted Gaskell</a> versus a <a href="Tommy%20Lawton">Tommy Lawton</a> XI in April 1954.
Management career.
Manley managed Cheshire County League club Northwich Victoria, with whom he began his career as a player, between March and October 1954.
Personal life.
Manley served in the <a href="RAF">RAF</a> during the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>. After his retirement from football, he became the licensee of a <a href="pub">pub</a> in <a href="Northwich">Northwich</a>.
Honours.
Manchester United
